content:
Could you consider replacing "unique characters" with "distinct characters"?

"Unique" is ambiguous and in fact there is another extremely similar Clash where "unique character" means "only count this character if the number of occurrences of this character in the string is exactly 1", which is different from "if a character appears more than once, count it only once".

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice problem with a short solution (at least in Python), but still not completely trivial. The problem statement is clear and the test cases are well-chosen.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: An exquisite clash, readily solvable with utmost ease within a brief span of 5 to 10 minutes. Swiftly, a posh solution in Swift. ðŸ˜Žâœ¨

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Difficulty is fine. Not too hard, but still one has to think a bit about it, while doing the implementation. Test cases are fine. Can be done in shortest and fastest mode (not in reverse-mode I think, but this was also not suggested). I understood the description immediately (although I am not a native english speaker)
Works for me. Understood the description of the task, difficulty was fine. Tests were okay I think. It is suitable for fastest and shortest mode.

Please refer to "distinct" or "different" characters, instead of "unique" characters.
"Unique" could be interpreted as "only appears once in the word".
For example, in Common Test 1, "programming" has 9 distinct characters (PROGAMIN), and 5 unique characters (POAIN). "python" has 6 distinct and 6 unique characters, so the sorting could go one way or the other.
Good puzzle, though.

Suggest you to switch to WIP first to fix the following issues and have further reviews.

Input
* Please change "The input consists of a single line containing" to "<<Line 1:>>".

* Please delete "Each string consists only of Latin alphabet letters (both uppercase and lowercase)."

Constraints
* Please add:
Each string in the input consists of lowercase English letters only.

Game modes
* It may be too difficult to guess the requirement in Reverse mode. Suggest to disable it.

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar but different. Please revise the cases accordingly.

* Except for the first case, all output is the same as the original input after sorting. Please revise the cases such that it's not always like that.

Thanks.
Hi everyone! This is my first Clash of code game! BE NICE <3
The Description and Output sections still mention "unique".

There are still some issues:

Input
* Please change "The input consists of a single line containing" to "<<Line 1:>>".

Cases
* Test 1 and Validator 1 are the same. Please make them different.

* Try to create some cases where the words are of different lengths but same number of unique characters.

* I'll comment on the revised cases further when you've done the above changes.

Thanks.

Input
* Please add "space-separated" before "words".

Cases
* The cases look much better now. Good work.

* "Static string" test violates the constraint because it contains special characters. Please fix the case.

* Test 5 and Validator 5: I would like to see at least 12 words of a mix of everything here:
â€¢ same length, same no. of unique characters
â€¢ different lengths, same no. of unique characters
â€¢ same length, different no. of unique characters
â€¢ different lengths, different no. of unique characters

The easiest way: just use the statement (using lowercase letters only and removing all punctuations)!

Input to Test 5 can be: your task is to sort these strings in descending order based on the number of unique characters in each string

Input to Validator 5 can be: if two strings have the same number of unique characters their order should remain the same as in the original list

Thanks.

Almostâ€¦

Input
* Please add "space-separated" before "words".

Cases
* Validator 5 is good, and now please make Test 5 very similar to that case.

Thanks.
Sorry for a lot of mistakes, I'm still learning. It seems to be ready!
No worries. Seems ok now. Thanks!
